articles.headline: $500 Million and Apology From Goldman
articles.snippet: Criticized over bonuses, Goldman Sachs said it was working with the billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett in a $500 million project to help 10,000 small businesses.
articles.abstract: Criticized over bonuses, Goldman Sachs said it was working with the billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett in a $500 million project to help 10,000 small businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: How much good will can an apology  and half a billion dollars  buy? A lot, Goldman Sachs is hoping.

articles.headline: Cellphone Apps Challenge the Rise of E-Readers
articles.snippet: Some readers prefer the convenience of small-screen smartphones to e-readers.
articles.abstract: Some readers prefer the convenience of small-screen smartphones to e-readers.
articles.lead_paragraph: With Amazon’s Kindle, readers can squeeze hundreds of books into a device that is smaller than most hardcovers. For some, that’s not small enough.
articles.byline: By Motoko Rich and Brad Stone

articles.headline: A Stimulus That Could Save Money
articles.snippet: A “cash for caulkers” program has the potential to get contractors working again, as well as keep more money in homeowners’ pockets.
articles.abstract: A “cash for caulkers” program has the potential to get contractors working again, as well as keep more money in homeowners’ pockets.

articles.headline: Philadelphia Gives Homeowners a Way to Stay Put
articles.snippet: A program in Philadelphia has enabled hundreds of troubled borrowers to retain their homes.
articles.abstract: A program in Philadelphia has enabled hundreds of troubled borrowers to retain their homes.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA  Christopher Hall stepped tentatively through the entranceway of City Hall Courtroom 676 and took his place among dozens of others confronting foreclosure purgatory. His hopes all but extinguished, he fully expected the morning to end with a final indignity: He would sign over the deed to his house  his grandfather’s two-story row house; the only house in which he had ever lived; the house where he had raised three children.

articles.headline: Labor Fight Ends in Win for Students
articles.snippet: The college anti-sweatshop movement persuaded Russell Athletic to agree to rehire 1,200 workers in Honduras.
articles.abstract: The college anti-sweatshop movement persuaded Russell Athletic to agree to rehire 1,200 workers in Honduras.
articles.lead_paragraph: The anti-sweatshop movement at dozens of American universities, from Georgetown to U.C.L.A., has had plenty of idealism and energy, but not many victories.

articles.headline: New Leader at Lazard Is an Insider
articles.snippet: The appointment of Kenneth M. Jacobs ends weeks of speculation over the successor to Bruce Wasserstein, who died in October.
articles.abstract: The appointment of Kenneth M. Jacobs ends weeks of speculation over the successor to Bruce Wasserstein, who died in October.
articles.lead_paragraph: For much of the modern era, Lazard was known for the internal strife that at times threatened to wreck the now 161-year-old investment bank. Few issues were more contentious than the firm’s leadership.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced
